summary: Young Sammy Fabelman falls in love with movies after his parents take him to see "The Greatest Show on Earth." Armed with a camera, Sammy starts to make his own films at home, much to the delight of his supportive mother.

reviews.content: The plot is beautiful and the performances are incredible. Although it is not risky and plays it safe, it is the stereotype of "the perfect cinema".
A really good biopic !

It starts well but falls into the trap of another dysfunction family being considered good entertainment, and fails to progress to the more interesting phase of Spielberg's career.

When films about films are made, most expect it to just be Hollywood stroking its own ego, but that's not the case here. Here the focus is on the purpose of films and why people are drawn to them, whether they are watching or making them. We can also see the impact that films can have throughout and the effects they can have on people. I wish more films would go as deep as this one did on the subject. Also, we have a memoir on one of the most prolific directors of our time, directed Steven Spielberg himself. When these two things are combined, it makes for a great picture. Even though it is 2 and a half hours long the time flew by and the story kept me engaged the entire time. Also, the performances the entire cast gives is top tier. Michelle Williams though is the real standout. She could easily win the Oscar for Best Actress. Even though it's Spielberg's story, she is basically the second main character. As an avid watcher and lover of film, this is by far my favorite of the year. Spielberg put so much of himself into making this and it really shows. It's his most personal film yet and is a true masterpiece. If you love films, you owe it to yourself to see this one.

For a masterful storyteller like Spielberg with a heartening passion in the edge, he would considerably be worth a subject to pitch a biographical film on, but he's proven that no one can tell a better life story than him since he's capable under true expressionism besides authenticity. Rather directly, he went on semi-autobiography direction whereas he can transfer his own story into representative characters, even if they're mostly still identifiable through his perspective. Triumphant once again, we're given the film-loving roots plus the straining difficulties stemming from personal, discouraging affairs, and the genuine nostalgia of our own growth with thorough touches refusing to leave any unresolved notes. We're introduced to his inspirations and managed to pick out subtle references to his previously acclaimed classics, as part of his cinematic venture's thoroughness whilst revisiting his past and curve it as a narrative.

Praiseworthy for all it can be, it seems Spielberg's main aim was towards the performative showcases perfectly embodying the self and spiritual identification only he can see happily like opening a time capsule to his past that led him onto an amazing path. Remarkably cast and brilliantly performed, particularly few at their best, as they're the true center in this honest, exceptionally scripted intimate portrait under the maintained trademarked magic dimmed down to a more personal level. If we were to determine where this film would rank in defining its release year's best of the best, it to show the formation of a cinephile's originated love that helps nurtured the cinema whilst reliving those nostalgic beginnings of mostly cherished times then deciding to project those memories personally and faithfully dramatized for a full circle momentum. (A-)
It might go a little too long, but I didn't mind the 150-minute runtime, because The Fabelmans is so relatable and beautifully shot and it is one of Steven Spielberg's best movies.

Amazing movie, just incredible. As usual, Steven Spielberg delivers an incredible story, and this time, about his own childhood and how movies impacted his life. Loved the performances, specially from Michelle Willians, and I think this movie deserved at least one Oscar. For me, the best movie of the year, an absolute masterpiece.

One of Steven Spielberg's outstanding characteristics besides being a pioneer and a master director, especially in his works of old is his versatility. He has dipped his feet in almost all kinds of genres and has succeeded in his own right – science fiction to top them all, adapted screenplays, original war-time stories, adventures, et al appealing to an audience of all ages. It wasn't going to be too long until we would have seen him creating something based on his own formative days.
"The Fabelmans" is pretty much his story shadow-played through a fictional family. One would have expected this sooner from him, but apprehension of the possibility that such a personal creation could hurt his parents held him back, even though his sister Anne had written something for him to direct almost a couple of decades back. His mother and father passed away in 2017 and 2020 respectively.
The film starts with the little boy Sammy's first brush with cinema, and his awe and anxiety towards the scary images on the silver screen, way back in 1952. One can possibly relate to Sammy's curiosity and attraction towards the fantasy of replicating a train crash he had seen in the film, using a model train. And then filming it using his father's camera, and his mom's sheltered encouragement. 
Sammy is immediately taken up by that magic of capturing moving images, his control over creating something fantastic, adventurous, and pursues it with passion.
There is the trademark Spielberg aura of a young family's dynamics – sunny disposition, chaos, happiness, joy and squabbles as Sammy's family grows and his parents Mitzi (Michelle Adams) and Burt (Paul Dano) are now parents of two more girls, younger to Sammy. The touch of typical American-Jewish family culture is natural and I think quite intriguing for those alien to it. I loved the playful moments watching the toddlers have their way.
As Sammy grows up into his teens (played by Gabriel LaBelle), persistently pursuing his passion by making home-made movies with his friends pitching in as actors, he discovers that all may not be as uncomplicated as it looks in his family.
The overall play and flow of the story is nothing outstanding – it almost feels like a typical youth's story growing up with his family in the ‘50s and ‘60s, though Sammy's attraction to making movies right from his toddler-hood is embedded with a personal touch and dedication by Spielberg. His candidness at telling some hard truths of his story is also commendable.
The main supporting cast of Paul Dano, Michelle Williams and Seth Rogen are good in their places, giving LaBelle the spotlight as much as possible. Michelle Williams is quite intense and shines through a great many emotions and moods, especially with her eyes. Judd Hirsh is almost miss-able with a cameo-like appearance, but his act is a reminder to me that it doesn't matter how long your presence on the screen is; if you have a crackerjack burst of histrionics and a good monologue (remember Jack Nicholson's explosion in "A Few Good Men" (1992) or Anne Hathaway in "Les Misérables" (2012)), there is a good chance you will be recognized.
I was really taken by Julia Butters' cameo as Reggie, Sammy's younger sister at a key moment in Sammy's life. It's not much but it is a small gem. One might remember her (I definitely do!) as the little girl who bantered with and gave some life lessons to Leonardo DiCaprio's brooding character in "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" (2019) like a wise old soul. Someone to watch out for.
It's a great ode by Spielberg to his story and his ever-growing passion for film-making and pioneering innovations that paved way for the directors who would weave visual magic on the screen.
tom hanks great actor

What an amazing story and look into the life of a brilliant writer and director.  This is a story that was well worth the wait and yet I'm very glad it was finally told.  A boys dreams come to life while dealing with every day life and some hard ship along the way.  What a story.

A beautiful, moving story based on the life of the Great Steven Spielberg.  It touches on so many aspects of American culture and family culture  that most of us can relate to in some way. I was completely captivated and entertained from beginning to end. A triumph! Bravo!

Great film-making. Many people said it was too slow so I came in expecting that, but I found the pacing to be just right. I find that most memoirs skip through the years too haphazardly. The Fablemans spent just the right amount of time on each critical time in Spielberg's childhood. It's cool to see an adult's understanding of his childhood played out.
I loved this movie! Great story telling. Judd Hirsch rocks.

This movie is loosely based on Steven Spielberg's life growing up in the 1960's and a love letter to movies and filmmaking. 

After being taken to his first movie, Sammy Fabelman discovers his love for movies and we follow him as he grows up and aspires to be a filmmaker. His father treats this as a hobby and his mother encourages his love of creating art. During this time, we follow the family through different dynamics, social issues, and following your dreams. 

As a lifelong fan of movies, I have to say I loved this movie. It was amazing to watch someone begin their filmmaking journey and see it evolve over time. Especially knowing that this is loosely based on Steven Spielberg's life and he is one of my favorite filmmakers. 

Also, I enjoyed watching the family dynamics. They showed real highs and lows within a family and the generational differences on what they believe is a viable career (seems like something that will never end). 

My only criticism of the movie was that it was a little bit on the long side. There were just a few scenes that I didn't feel were completely necessary to the story. 

If you have the opportunity to watch this movie, I say take the time to sit down, snuggle up, and enjoy. It is a great reminder to follow your dreams, work hard, and do whatever it takes to make them come true. I always appreciate the reminder that we only have one life so it's our job to make it the best we can. The best looks different for each of us, but it's our responsibility to shoot for the things that will make us feel fulfilled. Nobody else is going to make it happen for you, so snag every opportunity.
Boring. If you have a gameboy , you're gonna need it

The acclaim eludes me here. FABELMANS is a decent coming-of-age tale, told with skillful attention to detail, but the film adheres to its form so faithfully that it often feels generic--you've seen this movie before. We wouldn't have much reason to care about this story if we didn't know who the protagonist would become, and at 2.5 hours, it starts to feel like an exercise in self-indulgence. The film expresses a love for the magic of movies, but unfortunately it doesn't manage to recreate that magic.

The Real ET

The Fabelmans tell stories to themselves. Mr. Fabelman is a scientist who tells himself that he loves his work, wife and family and that Benny is his best friend. Mrs. Fabelman tells herself that she is the creative one who loves her family and that her secrets are her own business. But, as the young protagonist Sam Fabelman learns, these fables are not really true. He learns his mother really loves Benny and not his father - and his mother confirms this when confronted - and that his father may not actually be his father.

Steven Spielberg's origin story bears a strong resemblance to two films that came out in the early 1980's - ET (his acknowledged favourite) and Fanny and Alexander By Ingmar Bergman. Both are family sagas about divorce, youthful passions and strange events with a tinge of magic. It is a story of his passion for film and his genius for making films, which started very early and as of this film, hasn't yet stopped. Film as autobiography has never been so blatant or accomplished than this, nor as kind and perceptive. Paul Dano is Burt (his dad), a brilliant, bumbling, slightly cold man who has been cuckholded by Michelle Williams (his flamboyant and slightly crazy mother) with his best friend Benny ( Scott Rudin).  Gabriel La Belle (Sam) learns about film making and life, with all its ups and downs, in this unique, confessional film. It is brilliantly scripted by Spielberg  and Tony Kushner, shot with great care by the director  and the cast is impeccable. That this film was ignored by the Oscars is a terrible insult to Spielberg  and the cast, and to film making itself. It is never gimmicky, always emotionally acute and paced with great skill.

It was even better than All Quiet on the Western Front, my previous best of 2022. A classic.

The story-line never fails . . .of course this is based on young Spielberg's own coming-of-age. Sweet, smart, and impeccably  produced and directed -- of course it's Spielberg!. Yes, it was a bit long but I lost track of the time. Highly recommended for all audiences!

He meets his girlfriend, is it love? We don't know, the relationship seems impersonal. 10 minutes later he proposes to her, she refuses. But is he unhappy because of that or because of his parents' divorce, maybe everything is too much for him? Never mind - next scene short reconciliation (?) with his mother and haha tells that his girlfriend broke up with him. Heartbreak? Who knows, the film must go on, because Hollywood is still missing. For that, there is also another 10 minutes. And in the end, the film is still way too long.

So, I watched this movie three times in the last few months at the cineplex. The emotional punch lost a bit of its glimmer by the third viewing. But I still enjoyed it. This might be the closest thing we will ever get to an auto-biography from director Steven Spielberg. It's okay. I am grateful for the story. And I am thrilled to watch director David Lynch portray the gruff John Ford.

Excellent performances throughout (but especially by Michelle Williams as Mitzi Fableman). Spielberg weaves his magic while transporting us back to the 50s and 60s with his usual attention to detail in this autobiographical coming of age story. A moving story of complex family relationships told with love and forgiveness.
A boring movie with no original or artistic quality in cinematography, music, script, storytelling... Just uninteresting.
I loved seeing what shaped Steven Spielburg into the excellent film maker he is today. Great movie, I really enjoyed watching it.

There's a lot in this movie: it's a coming of age story about an aspiring filmmaker, it's a soap opera about a family of 7 and their peripatetic journey around the country as dad gets promoted, it's about bullying in high school, and it's about science vs art. It's also beautifully filmed, wonderfully acted, and includes a cameo from director John Ford as played by David Lynch, giving a succinct introduction to keeping your films interesting. As a summation of everything Steven Spielberg has learned up till now, and as one of his most personal, most autobiographical films, it is very entertaining and watchable, packed with cute digressions, humour, and a humanistic story. It also suffers from Spielberg's typical weaknesses. I guess that makes it a great auteurist film.
Really good movie.  Little agenda other than entertainment which is a fresh concept this year!
This is how a movie should be. Excellent!

All but a handful of Spielberg's movies wallow in maudlin sentimentality, but this one dives into the deep end. Most of his movies have predictable plots and, especially, endings. The main reason is that he spent his whole career remaking the types of movies he watched as a kid. 
His schtick apparently resonates with the movie-going masses, if ticket sales and acclaim are indicators. But then, so does the Rocky, Star Wars, and Fast & Furious franchises. Success and acclaim doesn't guarantee quality, as the annual winners of Grammy, Emmy and, yes, Oscars proves.
Well, this is Speilberg's tribute to himself and all his noble aspirations and mawkish, childlike wonder. It's a step up from a relative bringing out family videos, but at least those have an honesty about them.
Manipulative and self-aggrandizing, he apparently thought his enthusiasm would transmit to the audience. It doesn't.
Good luck at the Oscars, Steve.

every picturemaker has an origin story; they all have a moment of realization when they knew the true magic of what cinema can do and Steven Spielberg has to have the biggest flex in telling his own story of filmmaking through film itself.

sammy is taken by his parents Mitzi and Burt Fabelman on his first trip to the movie theater to watch Cecil B. DeMille's The Greatest Show on Earth. a nervous sammy watches in horror with mouth-agape fascination, as a pair of circus trains collide. to us, as 2022 audiences, the crash effects are crude and the scene is pretty lackluster, but to sammy in 1952, it truly is, The Greatest Show on Earth.

on the ride home, sammy's parents are debating if the movie was too scary for him but sammy says nothing, still wondering what he saw and that night, he goes to bed dreaming of trains. we then see sammy screaming for his mom at the top of his lungs and we instantly assume The Greatest Show on Earth has given him the Greatest Nightmare on Earth. alas, that isn't the case. sammy is jauntily jumping in bed and he knows exactly what he wants for Hanukkah: A Train Set. he then recreates the crash scene from The Greatest Show on Earth with his train over and over until his mother gives him the family's 8mm camera to shoot his own version of the sequence. she thinks that the camera will get the crashing trains out of his mind, or at least encourage him to stop smashing the very expensive toy around. although it does happen, it's not quite what you'd expect; instead, sammy has now transferred his interest from the train to the camera and once he did, he never let it go as evident from the film and his director itself.

what's most intriguing about this film is that you can tell, that even after 70 years, the real Steven Spielberg remains equally obsessed with movies. he's obviously learned a lot about how to make them since 1952; but he has never lost sight of the why.

the performances in this film are just heartbreaking and beautiful. paul dano has never had a bad performance in his entire career and his streak remains intact. and what's even more impressive, he has given us the role of a psychopath on a murderous spree and that of a loving, heartbroken father wanting what's best for his boy both in the same year. truly one of the best actors of our time. michelle williams OMG. what an absolute icon. this might be her most nuanced, emotionally-wrecking role to date and that shows. she was obviously the best part of the film for me because although the film never antagonizes paul dano's character (because he truly is the nicest person to exist who thinks rationally and is confined to reality), you know that he and michelle william's character can't stay together for long. they eventually have to seperate. the film uses this plot point like a chekhov's gun waiting to fire, a powder keg waiting to blow and steven builds up to that moment of lives being shattered with utmost delicacy. even the after-effects felt due to that are felt to the core and just brilliantly written. Gabriel LaBelle honestly is literally me. he is afraid, emotional, unsure of what to do in life if not following his true passion and even willing to sacrifice that passion for the sake of the family. truly a standout performance and I wish to see more of him in future films. rest of the performances are also really great and not a single loose thread.

the background score. 2022, a year of such great musical numbers and background scores. we have avatar 2' action packed score, babylon's trumpets, and the batman's epic and rousing theme (which I still think is the best score of the year and the academy does a real disservice to michael giacchino by not even nominating it). just when we thought we had it done and dusted, john williams rose from the ashes and gave us the beautiful score of this film. truly some exceptional work here. each and every single one of the piano pieces are beautiful and I desire to have this on vinyl.

the cinematography is also beautiful and not wanting to say much here without spoiling the absolute beauty of the shots, the 2 best scenes of the film for me are michelle williams gracefully performing in front of the car headlights in a gorgeous white gown and the last shot of the film which skillfully shifts the horizon from the middle to bottom.

I'm just happy that even though I had the chance to watch this at home, I decided to wait for that theatrical experience and got the best out of it.

P.S.: truly bummed and shocked to see this film's box office failure. cinema is truly dying and only we can save it guys. please go for this film in the theatres if you can because this is spielberg's most personal film to date and it deserves your attention.
As Spielberg as it can be, his special way to make stories shine makes The Fabelmans already a classic.

Outstanding acting by all actors.

This coming-of-age drama directed and co-written by Steven Spielberg  is a semi-autobiographical story loosely based on Spielberg's adolescence and first years as a filmmaker, told through an original story of the fictional Sammy Fabelman, a young aspiring filmmaker who soon discovers a shattering family secret and explores how the power of films can help him see the truth. It is a nostalgic and beautiful look that also acts as an ode to the film industry and in which Spielberg shows us what shaped him into becoming one of the most beloved filmmakers of our time and how he lived through the antisemitism he had to endure in his early years. The film is masterfully made, it is a stunning spectacle and Michelle Williams delivers the most incredible and human performance of her career and one could expect great things from newcomer Gabriel LaBelle. Also, John Williams's score shines bright as usual.

I haven't read what anyone else thought yet, but to me this was a beautifully shot, poignant, warm coming of age tale. It was a pleasure to get lost in this period piece and watch the main character stories play out. The mother character was particularly relatable and the balance between loss and humour throughout was just right for such an epic film.
Sensitive. Displays vulnerability on the perfect level and, well… Spielberg's perfect photograph. Just amazing!
The immense Build up to the end ruined me. I would've rather watched Morbius Twice in a row then have to experience the saddening end again.
This felt more like a made-for-tv movie.  Michelle Williams gives a great performance, but the film is just okay.

Nice story of how the tribulations of growing up in a somewhat dysfunctional family, with high expectations for college completion, ended up producing a Steven Spielberg, who found his way into the movie industry on his own. Acting was outstanding, and a heartwarming story.
Really enjoyed the story and the actors
Movie was completely pointless and WAY too long

A thoroughly enjoyable movie. It was interesting too see how his passion for movies started and it is really a movie about a family of the times. 
I felt as though it could have continued for another hour, the ending was a surprise, which left a feeling of an unfinished project. A sequel would be welcome too continue the story.
Good storyline could have used a stronger ending.

I now know why it didn't do so well at the box office. If Spielberg had stuck with the main character's discovery and joy of filmmaking, it would have been a more fascinating and appealing film. Instead, a huge part of the movie is wasted with the story about the dark secret the family has. If the film had been as brilliant and entertaining as the final scene, I would have given it at least 4 stars.

What a weak and sad attempt by a fearful master too scared to really show the truth and ignore the glory of the past's mythos. This film has no guts. It's heavy-handed poppycock and pure drivel, the desperation to show himself as a true artist is so tangibly evident it's embarrassing. This film has no oomph, no get-up-and-go! Most of all it's a selfish film about a self-centered filmmaker who, least of all, knows anything about himself. This is far from greatness. This is call lipstick on a pig. You made your mark Mr Spielberg, you have even made some remarkable films of great artistic value. Time to take a break...

Enjoyable, incredibly well acted, but not your traditional Spielberg-type movie, but that’s a good thing. Slowly paced, much more of an ‘artsy’ vibe than SS’s typical style with his historical and sci-fi epics. It’s all good, we really liked it.
Very good early life story of Steven Spielberg. Loved the ending with John Ford.

This is an odd and disappointing movie. I couldn't decide whether this movie is really about Spielberg's childhood or about his infatuation with his mother. It is very well done from a purely technical standpoint but the story is self-serving, slow developing, with a kitschy overtone and peppered with odd scenes that I found difficult to decipher except for probably Spielberg who seems more intent on working out his own childhood emotional trauma than anything else. If this movie had been directed by any one other than Spielberg, it would be a flop and no one would talk about it. When you are Spielberg, you have earned the right to produce this kind of movie late in your career, I guess.
A sleeper hit: I had no expectations going in and enjoyed the movie through and through. I felt like part of the family at the end. An inspiring film.

In a manner similar to Kenneth Branagh's "Belfast" of last year and Alfonso Cuarón's "Roma" a few years before that, "The Fabelmans" finds a filmmaker delving into their past in semi-autobiographical fashion, trying to make sense of their upbringing and what made them who they are. Here, it's Steven Spielberg in the director's chair and, as in "Belfast" and "Roma," the director's whole soul is on display for the world to see. Reverent, earnest and occasionally cheeky, this film leans further away from the traditional trappings of the Hollywood biopic, opting instead to tell a coming-of-age tale that's freer in form than I was expecting. In any event, it's undeniably fascinating to see any filmmaker mulling over the different elements of their own life and then applying artistic flair to it in turn. There's something even more surreal, however, in having that filmmaker be the literal person whose last name is most closely associated with the profession of filmmaking itself. Definitely a solid watch.

I don't recall ever wanting to watch a movie where Steven Spielberg just masturbates over himself, but here we are! There really wasn't much of a story here. Just because we love his movies, doesn't mean his life was really a story worth telling. The only good part was David Lynch (and that's already an odd thing to point out.)

Absolutely loved this amazing piece of moving art from the the genius.  How painful his coming of age period was discovering his loving mother's secret.  One can see Spielberg's trajectory into his brilliance.  A remembrance of how our childhood shapes our lives.
Picture was long, but very good..
Wonderful period piece and enlightening depiction of Steven Spielbergs upbringing.  A trip down memory lane for some over 50.  Acting was spot on and impressive.
I enjoyed this movie but found it quite slow moving and very long

I think this is probably one of Michelle Williams' best performances. The Fabelmans is a great film and has the amazing backdrop of cinematic talent and perseverance while in the midst of real issues and family dysfunction. The types of things that many artists deal with, and yet woven together with such finesse that it's not overly sad making it possible to deliver a plethora of remarkable performances conveying authentic and diverse emotional moments through the eyes of Sammy Fabelman.
Liked it, yet a bit slow moving at times!
I really appreciated the depiction of the relationships between the characters. It was a beautiful film and kept me engaged the whole time.

A touching tale of people who love each other enough to pursue what their hearts tell them, even if it means going their own ways. And a story of the power of filmmaking - how it can manipulate reality, how it can reveal painful truths, how it can refocus your life if you are driven to create art. A beautifully filmed semi-biopic about Steven Spielberg's coming of age, as written by Spielberg and Tony Kushner.

This is a long movie but time flew for me, first the intriguing tale  of how a brilliant director got his start,  but also the conflict every artist, writer,  filmmaker feels between art and family. The Fabelmans are charming,  eccentric,  troubled.  One  minute one envies their family solidarity the next one wants to escape it. Brilliant performance by Paul Dano as Spielberg's kindly,  long suffering,  gifted in his own way but typically shortsighted protective father.  I loved the director's passion,  empathy even his misguided teenage love affair full marks for humour observation and poignancy and if in doubt you have to stay to the end to see David Lynch's  cameo role as John Ford

As a Spielberg fan, I wanted to love this movie. The beginning gave me reason to hope, but the teenage years dragged with some ridiculous plot points that failed to make me laugh or cry — they served only to remind me that I was watching a movie. A real disappointment.

I've always been a big fan of Steven Spielberg. His films like Jurassic Park, Schindler's List and especially the Indiana Jones trilogy. While The Fabelmans doesn't reach the levels of any of those films it's still a really great edition to his filmography. On the surface, The Fabelmans can seem weird. "Why would you make an autobiography about yourself" is what someone might ask and while "pretentious" might be the first thing that comes to your mind, The Fabelmans doesn't feel that way. The film honestly feels more like a Spielberg therapy session than a Spielberg biopic. It feels more like Spielberg coming to terms with who his parents were and why they mean so much to him especially his Dad and how they influenced him into making films. As with most of his films, Spielberg's directing is great and it feels much more personal than it has since probably the late 90s or early 2000s. The cinematography as well is gorgeous at points and the performances are mostly all pretty top notch. Paul Dano, Seth Rogen and Gabriel LaBelle all did a fantastic job here. Michelle Williams was good but her performance was more mixed in my opinion. Sometimes she was really good and sometimes she was just a bit much. John Williams's score was great as well. Nowhere near his best work but still some really good and nice music. I would say that the film doesn't become truly great up until the last 30 minutes. Everything else before that is good but it definitely can feel slow for good portions of the film. Once we get to the High School prom though is when the film becomes great. It has some really great and emotional scenes along with an absolutely hilarious cameo from David Lynch and a really fun final frame. I don't think this is anywhere near Spielberg's best films but it's still a great edition to his filmography and I would definitely recommend checking it out.

This one gets forgiven of a lot of sins because it's about Steven Spielberg, written by Steven Spielberg, and directed by Steven Spielberg.

A biopic is one of my favorite genres, but an autobiopic has some extra baggage, as we can see here. Coincidentally, Spielberg, who is 76 waited until both of his parents were dead to make this movie. And when you learn the secret he carried his whole life, you can see why.

The core conflict in the fictional Fabelman family is between "the scientists" represented by the father and "the artists" represented by the mother. Sammy Fabelman, who represents young Steven Spielberg, finds himself solidly on the artist's side. But once you decide you're an artist, you spend the rest of your life learning that art is pain, at least according to Uncle Boris.

One of the greatest story arcs is the change in the way Sammy views his parents, from perfect, strong, steady forces in his life to broken people, as unsure about things as everyone else. This happens as Sammy is growing up, trying to gain certainty is his own identity and aspirations.

Sammy's mom encourages her son to follow his heart, no matter what - a beautiful message which is somewhat tainted because at that time for her, following her heart meant leaving her husband and breaking up her family.

Michelle Williams, per us' is the best part of any movie she's in, no matter the haircut. Paul Dano is amazing as the family patriarch. Seth Rogen, still with his characteristic goofy laugh, plays a more serious role than normal, and he does it well.

It's an ode to film, and I love film, but I do think that Hollywood can easily drift into navel-gazing and a self-congratulatory posture that no one asked for at the drop of a hat. If you love film or love Spielberg, definitely see the movie, but overall I think it's too disjointed and personal to stand on its own as a great film, or even a good story.

This movie was an excellent story about a family gripping with mental illness, infidelity and divorce.   We are inspired by our parents and even flawed parents can inspire thier children.  Life is hard and peers can be cruel. Parents can be selfish , but determination and hard work can yield success.

This movie was slow and thoughtful.  Thank you for making a great story that came to life with  visually stunning sets and wonderful acting.
I like that type of movies but in this one I was really bored somehow. It didn't have anything specific original to keep my attention.

A vanity project that tarnishes a beloved filmmaker's legacy, The Fabelman's offers an oversimplification of United Statesian life in the 60's-70's through the lens of privilege. Steven Spielberg is arguably the single biggest name in the movie industry. The Fabelmans is a film he's been intending to make for decades, and with the onset of COVID and the subsequent lockdowns, he's finally had the time to formulate it. It's been said that's it all about the love of movies and how both watching and making them can be a transformative experience. But having sat down and watched it last night, I was surprised how much this theme often went by the wayside. The film, at its core, is about the family unit, which can be both loving and volatile, sometimes in equal measure. When the filmmaking element is involved, it's not overindulged or even especially romanticised. Our lead's passion for making movies is treated as a dream, an aspiration, but it's not presented as a crutch. It's not something you can run to when you're in despair and expect it to take your problems away. Sammy Fabelman uses the power of film to explore and examine his family, not to glorify them. It presents the development of cinematic technology and trends over a relatively brief but important period of time, and even offers a few glimpses into the filmmaking process, which Spielberg himself has said came from his own experience. Being semi-autobiographical, it offers a window into the personal life of one of our most acclaimed cinematic figures; a man whose films we all known, but who we have never really connected with on a personal level. I liked all the performances, even though a few teetered on the verge of melodramatic at times. It clearly comes from a place of compassion and earnesty, and that's what resonated so strongly with people. It's runtime of 2 and a half hours gives us the time to get comfortable with it characters, but it frequently leaves you checking your watch. Also, for a biopic made by and about a famous figure, it doesn't take a lot of risks or do anything we haven't seen before. Even the confrontations and arguments feel sanitised and even glossed over. For these reasons, it's a film I enjoy and admire, but would almost certainly never revisit unless it was for a specific reason, like if I was making a video, recording a podcast or writing a document on it. I'm very happy that Spielberg got to tell this highly personal story, and as predictably whimsy as it can be at times, its still a beautiful story that any fan of cinema should check out at least once.

I just wish that this film 'The Fablemans' would have gone into more detail about how he made those films, that would have been very interesting.

But showing his beginnings in a Jewish family that moved around the United States (NJ, to AZ, to CA) shed some light on the dysfunctionality of his family, his experiences with anti-semitism and the development of his ambition towards making short films with primitive cameras.

English Review

Despite its promising premise, Steven Spielberg's latest film "The Fabelmans" fails to hit the mark. With Paul Dano and Michelle Williams as opposites-attract parents and Seth Rogen as an uncle, the movie could've been a riveting look at the legendary filmmaker's childhood. However, their performances are overwrought and the movie's excessive focus on the perils of the relationship between Sammy's parents detracts from the story. Judd Hirsch adds some much-needed life to the film and Gabriel LaBelle does his best with the role, but the John Williams score sounds recycled and the editing is too laborious for a 150-minute movie. Ultimately, there doesn't seem to be any real urgency to "The Fabelmans" and it's unlikely to make much of an impact on the upcoming awards circuit; the casual movie fan can wait on this one.

As "The Fabelmans" (2022 release; 150 min.) opens, it is "January 10, 1952" and 6 yo Steven, urrr I mean Sammy, needs some serious convincing by his parents to go see "The Greatest Show On Earth", but when he does, he is overwhelmed. He wants to recreate the train wreck from the movie, and it's his mom who suggests filming it on an 8mm camera... At this point we are 10 minutes into the movie.

Couple of comments: this is Steven Spielberg's long-awaited film of his youth. I love and respect Spielberg, but this is Spielberg at his worst: sentimental and self-indulgent. There isn't a single aspect of the movie that I found interesting or redeeming. Why did Spielberg assume that his family's comings and goings, including his parents' marital challenges, would be so unique and hence interesting, when in fact this is what happened to millions and millions of families in the 50s and early 60s. As a complete aside, as most of you know Spielberg lived in Cincinnati until age 11, then moved to Phoenix. A significant early part of the movie plays out in Cincinnati, but there is not a single reference, none, to Cincinnati. Why? In contrast, the second that the family is moving to Phoenix, Arizona, the area is mentioned multiple times in the film. I find it curious, to say the least.

"The Fabelmans" premiered at last Fall's Toronto International Film Festival to immediate critical acclaim and then was released in US theaters just before Thanksgiving. Since then it has significantly underperformed at the box office (a mere $12 million after 7 weeks). The matinee screening where I saw this at the day after New Year's at my local art-house theater here in Cincinnati was attended well (I counted roughly 30 people). I honestly cannot think of any movie by Spielberg that is worse than this, and I cannot in good conscience recommend this to anyone. If you haven't seen this yet, please save yourself the time and money. You'll thank me later when you catch it streaming at some point.

Inspired by childhood events and his parents' divorce when he was a teenager, Steven Spielberg's 2023 Oscar contender, co-written with playwright Tony Kushner, is an intensely personal and introspective film, which is immensely easy to like and enjoy, mashing up multiple genres that include an aspiring film-maker's coming of age story, a divorce family drama and a high school rom-com. Gabriel LaBelle, in a grounded and winsome performance, plays Sammy Fabelman, Spielberg's substitute, while Michelle Williams has the showier part of his free-spirited mother, and Paul Dano takes the subtler and often overlooked role of his down-to-earth and more practical father. As Dad's career goes from strength to strength, resulting in his family's migration across the country, Mom's unhappiness with her marriage bubbles up to become something that's no longer containable. Structured as a movie of 2 halves, the sudden pivot mid-film from family to high school anti-Semitic bully drama can cause whiplash but there's a satisfying payoff when it's all threaded through to demonstrate the power of films and its importance in Sammy/Spielberg's life, which is appealing for me on a Cinema Paradiso level. Bar the final epilogue scene (which will delight Spielberg enthusiasts), the story here has universal appeal and application to any young person who has lived through a parents' divorce, but more cynical viewers understandably can find this a schmaltzy exercise in sentimentality. Thankfully the film handles it all with sophistication and masterly control, as the treatment of Sammy's discovery of a family secret and the subsequent confrontation with his mother demonstrate; and Spielberg's effortlessly dexterous and calibrated execution, with quaintly stylish visual compositions and fluid editing, blending in Sammy's film footage for additional authenticity and warmth, is how he gets away with it and why there's a difference between saccharine and Spielbergian.

I'm not sure this was made and why he thinks everyone needs to know the intimate family details, as really only he comes through as a good and rounded character, the majority are surely dusturbed to be portrayed. Could have been compacted into 30 mins as watching everyday Jewish home life isn't exactly compelling cinema ( unless it's "My Favourite Year")  if you've paid for a ticket. No doubt the critics will fawn over it though.
Beautifully told family and coming of age story with an excellent cast. Exquisitely filmed. An ode to the joy and power of movies and the art of filmmaking.

"The Fabelmans" is truly a love letter to film and about finding life's passions. The movie takes real moments from Spielberg's adolescence and pieces them together. It is fascinating to see the beginnings of the man who brought films such as "Jurassic Park" and "Indiana Jones" to life. Though it took a minute for me to become invested in the characters, once the pacing hit its stride, I was hooked. 

The film tackles difficult topics, such as racism and infidelity, without forcing an agenda. There is a truth to "The Fabelmans" that was uniquely charming. Spielberg is not afraid of silence, and some of the most memorable scenes are from those quiet moments. Rather than relying on words, facial expressions perfectly conveyed the message he wanted to tell. 

When the film started, I was concerned about the acting and the script. Some of the performances were stiff and felt pretentious, at least at first. It was evident that the pressure of portraying Spielberg's family was daunting for some of the actors. After about 20 minutes, the acting seemed more natural, and I was able to see the passion behind each performance.   

As the film is based on Steven Spielberg's childhood/youth, there were a lot of small stories over the 2 hour 30-minute runtime. At times, these individual scenes felt disconnected from the ultimate narrative. Similarly, some of the editing was choppy and out of place. Ultimately, the story came together, but there were some unnecessary stops along the way.

If you love films, you will find joy in "The Fabelmans". After finishing the movie, I felt inspired in a unique way. It is evident that Steven Spielberg put his heart into this project and that he tapped into deep, personal roots. As the Academy Awards approach, this film is a lock to win one, if not more of their seven nominations.

I’m a sucker for a good ending. Not without faults, The Fabelmans is, at the very least, a great coming-of-age film surrounding a boy with a passion for filmmaking. A visually pleasing movie with emotional scenes exalted by great performances, Steven Spielberg managed to keep me interested for nearly the entire 2 hour 30 minute runtime. Unfortunately this movie isn’t only meant to be a coming-of-age film, as it also attempts to tackle the protagonist’s love for film and how it affects his relationships with his family. “Art and family, they’ll tear each other apart.” At times throughout this film it felt as if it was abandoning that portion of the story and I started to lose interest. Aside from that, this movie did not have many, if any, other major issues and I can see myself going back to rewatch Steven Spielberg’s The Fabelmans.

For a director who has always prioritised entertainment over aesthetics and audience over auteur, The Fabelmans is an oddly discomfiting watch at times, even for a movie that seems to be trying to hit some emotional truths while maintaining the youthful protagonist's wide-eyed view of his chosen profession, movie-making. In a way, it's an homage primarily to the young Sam Fabelman's mother, and a nod to the maternal sacrifice required of her in choosing family over art, motherhood over music. This theme is repeated throughout the film, in scenes with his uncle - also with a toe in the movie business - where he tells Sammy that he'll be ripped apart by the choice between art and domestic life just as his mother, played by Michelle Williams, is.
There's an oddly unsettling quality to some of the 'happy family' scenes throughout, although the characters of Sammy's sisters are funny, natural, and just a tad anarchic themselves. In the end however, this emotional queasiness rises to the top, as Mimi's eccentricities tread a fine line between endearing artiness and pathological narcissism. The same tone is struck in ET as Elliott's mother strides distractedly around her chaotic post-divorce house, into which an actual extra-terrestrial has moved without her noticing, a fact that Spielberg plays on as she repeatedly crosses ET's path, highly strung and oblivious.
In The Fabelmans, however, Spielberg is reaching for something even closer to home - his own actual formation as a filmmaker. And like his protagonist Sam, he doesn't lack courage, drive, or even - as his sister points out - the necessary strange detachment. Neither do the depictions of his parents lack compassion or nuance. Not at all. But this doesn't make it an uncomplicated watch. It's as if, like Sam filming the anti-Semitic bullies in his school, he can't resist glorifying them and ingratiating himself at the same time. It's like a superpower, this creativity: in positioning the aesthetic superiority of the athletic blonde bully, he protects himself from the more dangerous aspects of his own 'underdog' status.
The Fabelmans are foregrounded as a Jewish family from the narrative get-go, and the movie certainly doesn't shy away from this fact. There are even bigger themes at play here though - life vs art; sacrifice vs responsibility; parenting vs freedom. For Jewish protagonist Sam Fabelman, the movies are a way of, as Mimi Fabelman suggests, 'controlling his anxiety' and, at the same time, winning over his detractors. It's a dangerous game though, as even the bully realises. Sam's portrayal of him as 'golden boy' is no less of a trap than Sam's role of underdog.
In the end however, it's the artistic conversation that matters most, as 'representer' and 'represented' grapple with their respective roles and come to an uneasy truce. 
The youthful Sam defends his high school movie by saying 'the camera sees what it sees.' But an old veteran like his mentor John Ford (keep an eye out here - pun intended - for David Lynch) knows better -  it's the ANGLE that tells the story...

THE FABELMANS, a semi-autobiographical account of the film's director, Steven Spielberg's childhood years, co-written by Spielberg and Tony Kushner, stars Gabriel LaBelle as the young, budding filmmaker Sammy Fabelman. Sammy's hesitant, yet supportive parents, Mitzi and Burt Fabelman are played by the luminous Michelle Williams and the convincing Paul Dano. Also in the film, Judd Hirsch making a short but memorable appearance in his recent Best Supporting Actor Oscar-nominated performance as Sammy's cantankerous Uncle Boris. Spielberg pays homage to the wonders and realities of youth, dreams and love of cinema seen through the eyes of Sammy whose early life witnesses his mother's unrealized musical aspirations, his father's multiple job changes resulting in the Fabelmans various moves from state-to-state, and the ultimate breakup of his family following his parents divorce. All this going on while Sammy realizes and begins to nurture his own artistic talents for filmmaking. A highlight of the movie is an almost unrecognizable David Lynch who appears at the climax of the film as Iconic director John Ford who talks to Sammy about the importance of horizon in good filmmaking. Steven Spielberg is one of the great directors who is blessed with a true gift for storytelling and he accomplishes this, again with THE FABELMANS. You may recognize his abiding love for Indiana Jones in this film through the character of a handsome, tough on the outside, flawed on the inside high school track star, caught on camera on Ditch Day by 18 year old Sammy Fabelman. It's obvious Steven Spielberg never forgot him.

"The Fabelmans" is a movie loosely based on the true story of Steven Spielberg's own childhood. Produced after the death of his mother Leah Adler and using the fictional family name of the Fabelmans the movie focuses primarily on the iconic film makers family and the impact his parents divorce had on his young life.  "The Fabelmans" is rich in  exposing the influences behind classic movies like E.T. ( Set in a broken home ) and some early techniques at effects the film maker used to better his home movies. 

"The Fabelmans" starts in the 1950's with Sammy Fabelman experiencing for the first time the magic of cinema with his parents. Slightly traumatised by the movie, particularly a train crash scene it's from this emotional experience the first glimpses of becoming a film maker appear. Who of us that have delved into the arts ( film making, actors , singers , performers , etc ) didn't start off creating these types of home made replicas?  The idyllic family set up, with the ever growing confident and more adept young home movie maker,  becomes derailed when after editing his 8mm footage of a family camping trip he discovers all was not as he remembered.  The impact of what Sam discovers about his concert pianist mother and that fateful trip results in the eventual breakdown of his parents. 

As the movie moves into the early 1960's and Spielberg's high school years "The Fabelmans"touches on religion, race issues and first love. Due to the impact of that fateful camping holiday and therefore following a hiatus of not wanting to make any further home movies, Sam is persuaded by his girlfriend to film the end of school year beach party get together.  The impact of Sam's return to film making is clearly visible after the graduation film he produced is shown at the school prom to great acclaim.  

"The Fabelmans" is well documented as being a love letter to cinema but equally it is Spielberg's love letter to his family. This is the movies key fact, the acceptance of multiple things happening all at once. Vocation is driven by both fear and talent, loving relationships break down, and movies that appear simplistic are highly sophisticated. With an extremely satisfying ending " The Fabelmans" is a beautifully crafted work of art and remarkable insight into one of the most famous and influential directors Hollywood has ever produced

The cutesy charm of the first two thirds of this film helps the viewer understand the characters and sets the tone of this coming of age film. Anyone that has watched the Wonder Years Will be immediately familiar with format—the nostalgia, the examination of a family through the experience of one main character. But when that cutesy-ness lingers in the final third it morphs into out-and-out daytime TV melodrama. This film has a lot going for it but ultimately fails to close out its great ground work at the business end. All good coming of age films are relatable and complex, the best are profound and offer artistic insight in to our lives though the director's lens. Unfortunately the Fablemens fails to make the final leap despite the inclusion all the necessary complexities that should enable such a conclusion. It has complicated sexual relations, family relations, personal passions and an array of inequality and injustice that life provides—all inspired no doubt by the Wonder Years and Spielberg's own life. As expected, this is complemented with a lusciously beautiful presentation of 50s and 60s nostalgia. And mainly for these reasons it is an engaging and highly enjoyable film only let down by a garbled and somewhat rushed final step. Instead of showing a exploration and blossoming of the main character after multiple setbacks, failures and family shake ups, the Fablemens relies on an cameo (a very good one) from David Lynch to end on a suspenseful albeit smug final scene (smug because of the semi autobiographical nature of the film). Much like the rest of the film, the elements required are present in the final third but they are presented austerely and without the consideration and depth of emotion required to deliver the bit when the main character actually comes of age… I left the theatre with a strong suspicion that this was meant to be two films, or perhaps even a TV show. With better prep and an editor on the side of the viewer rather than, well, Spielberg, we might have got what we expected. Wilhelm scream count - 0.

Saw Steven Spielberg's THE FABLEMANS last night.
It's expected to receive major Oscar nominations today.
I have seen most of his films, and love the blockbusters, but don't like some of his titles. He is great with action, editing, lighting, etc., but generally misses the mark with dialogue scenes.
THE FABLEMANS is, to be honest and blunt, absolutely terrible.
It is supposed to be a fictional account of his foray into film-making at an early age, but comes across as a series of scenes which do not connect. There is no rhythm to the movie, and no actual storyline.
Truth: I left after the first hour. Walked out and away from this mess!
The cast, somehow up for the Screen Actors Guild Award for Best Ensemble, is awkward. Paul Dano, as the fictional boy's father, is miscast, seems to be trying too hard to be fatherly, and came across dazed.
Michelle Williams flounders. She never finds her center. Then again, she's given bizarre things to do like show us half-eaten food in her mouth and dance around in the woods.
Judd Hirsch hams it up, and eats the scenery, but not in a good way. He continues the stereotype of what a "Jew" is supposed to be. 
Seth Rogen gives the best performance in the hour I actually watched.
The scenes sit flat. No movement. The dialogue is dull. Who cares about Dad going on and on about IBM?
Spielberg has, frankly, lost his magic touch.
This is a movie that, somehow, won The Golden Globe for Best Picture.
Then again, NBC owns Universal Pictures.
NBC aired The Globes.
So...
THE FABLEMANS has no connection to its audience.
Grade: F

I've often said that one thing that all great movies have in common, is the ability to make time go by faster. This film has a runtime of 2hrs 31 mins and I can honestly say that every second of that flew right by. I was engaged and hooked into the story right from the very first scene. 

Ultimately this is a movie about people who are suffering. One is suffering for his family to love him, one is suffering for love, and one is suffering for his art.

It was interesting to see the instant connection that Spielberg had with movies. He was hooked as soon as he saw the train crash in "The Greatest Show On Earth." So much so, that he tried to recreate it and the rest is history as they say. 

The acting in this film was just phenomenal. You could really feel the internal struggle which plagued Paul Dano throughout the film. He knew his faults as a husband and father, but did  nothing to be better. He just kept on being a workaholic and this ultimately caused the downfall of the family.

Gabriel LaBelle Really shined as the main character. He slowly gains his footing into film making and uses it as an escape from his reality, but also as a means to show the truth. He persevered and eventually got what he wanted, a chance to break into the industry. He never had support from his father, he suffered for his art. We can ultimately see how Spielberg developed his style. 

Michelle Williams is the standout star in this one. She really portrayed her character well. Her pain at not being with the right person really felt real. She didn't even need to speak all her mannerisms and facial expressions did the work for her. She is a selfish as they come (even admits it) and I personally didn't like this. Why break up your family like that? Life will not always be exciting. You have a loving husband and wonderful kids and you threw it away to be with his friend. Shame on her.  

It  goes to show that you don't need to have any special effects or exploding cars to make a good movie. A great story will always triumph, and this movie certainly has. 

It's a must watch.

I loved Steven Spielberg's "The Fabelmans". A teller of tales is what a "fable man" does--which is exactly what a movie-maker does. The premier movie maker today is undoubtedly Steven Spielberg, and this movie is certainly his autobiographical masterpiece. This story of his formative years as he comes of age and learns to love film-making is so rich, so down to earth, and so appealing in its honesty, that we see and earnestly appreciate how his genius brain was shaped. His relationship with his parents (and to a certain degree with his sisters and his great-uncle) are central and inform what makes his movies so utterly heart-felt. His movies and his art grab you and hurt your heart--and that is exactly what this wonderful film does. Highly recommended!

We have to wait 5 months to have an opportunity to pay much more for a movie than if we just download it now?

Just got home from watching Steven Spielberg's latest film, The Fabelmans. 
What a brilliant film he has made. A semi autobiography paying tribute to his love for films from when he was only a young boy, while also diving deep into his humble up bringing. The film almost feels like a bunch of old home family videos collected over the years, documenting the Fabelmans story through the eyes of a young aspiring film maker, Sam Fabelman. We get a close look at how Sam Fablemans love for film making, eventually helps him uncover a dark family secret. One which will shape his family's entire future. The film focuses heavily around the joys and problems that families face, and there are elements throughout the film that we as an audience, can all definitely relate to one way or another to our own lives. It's so emotional, deep on so many levels. And what it means to follow one's heart, and the risks we take in order to live out our dreams.

While the film won't ever hit the heights of Spielberg's signature films, it really is a love letter to his passion of film making, a film that only a legendary director of his calibre, has earnt the right to make. Michelle Williams performance is absolutely phenomenal, she absolutely nailed it! She deserves a  nomination for best actress in a leading role at the Oscars, at the very least. While she was the stand out performance, every single actor in the film is magnificent. 
All in all, I walked out of the cinema extremely impressed, Speilberg has delivered a beautiful film, one which gives us a close look at what helped shape and inspire, one the greatest minds in the history of film making. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

The Fabelmans is an affectionate and emotionally resonant ode to the life of a family and the power of film. It has some small faults but overall it's a masterful film from a master of cinema. Director Steven Spielberg made a film based on his life and after reading his life story it's remarkably close to the truth. The film is basically divided into three parts. In 1952 New Jersey young Sammy Fabelman is taken to the movies for the first time and is awestruck. Sammy lives with his parents and two younger sisters. His father Burt is a computer engineer and lends Sammy his movie camera, where Sammy makes home movies. When Sammy is a teenager the family move to Arizona after Burt takes a job with GE. Sammy continues his love of film making small films with his friends. This part of the film really shows how one person can fall in love with the magic of cinema. The third part of the film I think is the most successful. The family moves to California, but the parents grow apart and Sammy gets bullied at high school. We see here strong emotional scenes that are handled with truth and honesty. This is a broadly entertaining film that even though at times early on veers into sentimentality it's easy to see how personal this was for Spielberg. It's an honesty portrayal of his parents and clearly shows how movies captivated him from a young age. The film is tender, funny and deeply human. It's filled with great performances but I especially loved Paul Dano and Gabriel LaBelle as Sammy. Spielberg is a true master and this fine film stacks up with his best.

I'm a big fan of Steven Spielberg and I probably love movies as much as he does. The Fabelmans isn't the love letter to movies that I was expecting. I think I wanted to see a Spielberg Cinema Paradiso. However, what I got was a lovely deeply personal portrait of Spielberg himself as a nascent filmmaker growing up in a complicated Jewish family.

My AMC finally brought The Fabelmans to my location and I'm so happy I got the chance to see it in theaters. This is such a wonderful film and the only reason I'm not giving it a perfect score is because of the runtime. Unlike Avatar, I don't think the 2 and half hour runtime of this movie was necessary. I think a good 20-30 minutes could have been shaved off and it would have had the same effect. Michelle Williams and Paul Dano are fantastic as the parents of this family. Williams really sells the idea of being a woman conflicted by her marriage. And Dano really shows off the range that he has, from the Riddler to start the year to this Father trying to keep his family together to end it. Seth Rogan delivers a fantastic dramatic performance, so much so that his trademark laugh feels so out of place here. Gabriel LaBelle is just fantastic in this. Not many people can keep you invested in a 2 and half hour long movie but he did here. I was invested in his story and now I'm invested in his career and where it goes from here. I've loved Julia Butters since her time on American Housewife but I haven't seen her since she exited the show and was replaced, but I'm so happy to see her here. It took me a second because she's so much taller now but she's great here and I'm happy to see she's still acting. Jeannie Berlin and Judd Hirsch have great small roles that really flesh out this family and make it more relatable and dynamic. David Lynch makes a really fun cameo at the end that I imagine was super fun to film. The Fabelmans is such a powerful movie about family and the wonder of seeing your first movie. They do such a good job showing us why a kid would be in love with movies and how they're made. Stephen Spielberg is such a genius filmmaker and you can tell the craftsmanship of this movie has been upped on every level. This is clearly a passion project for him and I'm so happy it's as good as everyone said. I just think some of the scenes could have been tighter so the runtime could have been a lot shorter. But the acting, story, and score are all so well done. I would definitely recommend heading out to see The Fabelmans, if your AMC is even playing it. 9/10. -Tyler

Before I launch into this review, here's a bit of background.  I was a teenage filmmaker, like the protagonist, who filmed my own productions with families and friends that I would then screen in church basements or high school auditoriums.  I was predisposed to LOVE this film, and indeed, at times, scenes felt like they were lifted straight out of my youth.
Alas, that was only about 20% of the time in this dull, over-wrought, over-long, poorly written snore fest that barely rises above the worst made-for-tv failing-family storytelling.  Part way through, I sensed that Spielberg himself must have been the chief writer.  I consider him something of a flawed genius.  When he turns his talents to suspense and action, he has no equal.  When he gives himself over to sentimentality, he's one of the worst.  To understand this better, think of two scenes from Jurassic Park...The terrifying T-rex night attack, and the sappy brachiosaur scene that feels lifted straight off of Saturday morning kids t.v.  How does the same filmmaker produce two such disparate scenes in one movie?  Fabelmans is 10 minutes of t-rex followed by 50 of brachiosaur.  
I sometimes wonder if Spielberg has an astute grasp on how human emotions work, since so many scenes feature odd and strange behaviours from the characters.  The arrogant jock gets weepy at a high school film screening that makes him look like an action hero.  Perhaps he's motivated by his guilt at how poorly he's treated the film-maker.  But I've known guys like this...and in that moment, at that point in his life, he'd be nothing but pumped up.  The realization that he may have treated others badly is something that would come much later in his life, if ever.  Ditto the strange emotions of the protagonist during his screenings, when he could barely look at the audience or the screen.  If film-making is your escape from everyday life, you'd be hyper-focused on your audience reactions and likely, on cloud 9, especially when you're getting a good reception.  My own screening experiences were very much like the film's lead, and they were unfailingly a thrill and a high for me.  Escapism at its very best, not a moment to be all introspective and weepy.  
Clunky, expository scenes and dialogue are rife.  There's a cameo by Judd Hirsch that is "deus ex machina" at its worst.  He literally drops into the movie to explain what the overarching theme is, and then is whisked away minutes later.  
I think my biggest beef with the film lies in the marketing.  The trailers and commercials make you think you're going to watch the story of a brilliant wunderkind using his wits and talents to reach the pinnacle of his art.  There's times when that's exactly what this is.  But it's never long before that's derailed and we are off to some other less interesting place for long long periods of time (I checked my watch more and more as it wore on). Hell, the kid even abandons his craft for a good chunk of the third act. The net result is about a half hour of an interesting movie buried in a tedious two and a half.  And my two movie-going partners concurred with all of the above.

THE FABELMANS, while not living up to the advertising hype, is still a captivating coming-of-age drama set during the post-World War II era. Based loosely on Steven Spielberg's adolescence, it follows the story of Sammy Fabelman, an aspiring young filmmaker who discovers a family secret and is forced to confront difficult truths about his past.

The film features excellent performances from its cast, particularly from its young lead, Gabriel LaBelle, who brings a nuanced vulnerability to the role, and Michelle Williams who is brilliant as Sammy's confused mother.

The cinematography is stunning, bringing an ethereal beauty to its scenes that transport viewers into another time. The movie also features captivating music from the era, tying in with the film's overall theme of nostalgia and remembrance. The intricate set design and cinematography also help to paint an effective picture of life in 1950s Arizona.

The Fabelmans is far from perfect due to its almost too-glossy look and the feeling that it doesn't dig deep enough, but it succeeds due to its strong performances and smart storytelling. It's a film that offers an inspiring glimpse into the power of film and its ability to help people confront difficult truths. Overall, I found it enjoyable and thought-provoking, and it left me feeling a little wiser for the experience.

In "The Fabelmans", Steven Spielberg reminds us why he loves the movies - movies are a powerful art form and impassioned mediums of expression, they blur the lines between reality and fantasy, they speak truths and can be deeply personal, and they stand the test of time. This is a masterful, paradoxical story crafted by one of cinemas most impactful directors about his upbringing as a novice filmmaker in a time when filmmaking, as we know it today, was in its infancy.

Spielberg tells his memoir through Sammy Fabelman, and he could have only dreamt about back in the 60s and 70s of capturing his younger years with this level of expertise and technological innovation. The film is not only a lesson about the history of film but an intricate exploration of film techniques and family dynamics.

There are many revelations and gutsy, tough themes in "The Fabelmans", but none speaks more strongly than that of the capabilities and evolution of film - that cameras often capture and preserve moments that can't be captured, or often go unnoticed, in real life.

This is proof that film is magic, a precious time capsule where Spielberg pays homage to the movies. Yet not everything is glossy, as we also get an intimate look at the challenges that come with marriage, parenthood, coming of age, bullying, and antisemitism. Yes, some scenes are emotionally charged, even painful, but others are beautiful and funny, and Spielberg's trademark moments of innocence, wonder, and awe shine through.

Top this masterwork with some great performances, especially by Gabriel LaBelle as Sammy and Michelle Williams as his mom, Mitzi, and you have one of the best films of 2022.

I enjoyed every minute of this movie, and all of the details in it were very important. I was fascinated to watch the impact of the art of  cinema on the gifted boy, and how his gift of art grew along with him as he matured. I grew up knowing a gifted ballerina my age, and watching an artist mature from child to adult is like watching God in action. Additionally, watching the family's move from east coast to west coast in the 1960s is also fascinating. All the scenes showing the children during that time period are good and really important, because the differences between the 2 coasts at that time were tremendous. My family and myself experienced the same emotions. The west coast's lack of tolerance, anti-semitism, the beach scene, are all examples of culture change that my siblings and I experienced. The parents were not aware of their children's struggles, probably because they were having their own struggles with the changes in roles and the norms in marriage during the 60s. The movie was very entertaining, everyone over 55 should identify with it. And for those under 55, watching this movie will  educate you about the American culture of the 1960s. That decade was very challenging to grow up in. Super movie for these 2 reasons and much more.

I don't think The Fabelmans is the masterpiece that others seem to believe it is. It's a very nice movie, but every film about filmmaking really needs to pull its weight and differentiate itself these days, because come Oscar season we seem to get a small handful of films about "the craft" that may or may not be pandering to members of the Academy, patting each other on the back over their choice of career. It's clear that there was passion and sincerity as Spielberg describes the totally-not-child-version-of-himself growing up and seeing the power of the camera, how it gave him a different perspective and a creative outlet. The stitches binding together Sammy's love of film and the observations he makes on his family's life make the two inseparable, but they don't necessarily add much in the way of insight to one another; this very lengthy film has some shockingly standard story beats - parents drifting apart, a couple of school bullies, a sense of professional aimlessness - that are all cinema ex machina'd by the restorative waters of a handheld camera. Film isn't treated so much as a salve, a placebo, or an escape in The Fablemans as much as it is a miraculous cure-all, and maybe it's that lack of realism (or cynicism?) that makes the wonder feel too sickly-sweet. Very likable, particularly the creativity that Sammy exhibits with his early filmmaking, but it seems odd for Spielberg, the creator of the blockbuster, to act as if the commercial side of cinema doesn't exist and it's easier to create this more easily digestible wonderland version. Or maybe I'm just cranky. 

Watching this so soon after Iñárritu's BARDO is an interesting experience; both are meditative pseudo-autobiographies on the role of film and filmmaker with heavy emphasis on family, but where Iñárritu chose to address cultural issues and experiment, Spielberg stayed relatively grounded and sentimental. Not a problem with either, more an observation.

But, perhaps that was the goal.  Unfortunately, it left theatre-goers getting up to get popcorn or visit the restroom because you wouldn't miss anything by leaving the theatre.   More editing of extremely long, unnecessary scenes, less time pouring over his childhood and more examples of him learning his craft, his professional experiences and rise to being an exceptional director (early work) would have been much more interesting and enlightening for the audience. Overall, this is an emotional ride as we witness the upbringing of the famous director, producer, and writer Stephen Spielberg. I found myself grinning with joy and feeling sad for the vast majority, and it's hard not to be curious and fascinated by the true story that the film presents. Performances from all the leads are stunning, touching, and impressive. Visually, this film is adorable and creative, and the score by composer John Williams is impacting. Sadly, some themes do overstay their welcome, and if minor edits were made here and there, the pacing could have been a bit tighter. Nevertheless, it's an incredible film, and I admire Steven Spielberg for sharing his heart and past experiences with the entire world of cinema.

Honestly, I didn't think it was well-made. It was disjointed and the elements were not assembled successfully: acting, writing, cinematography, score, etc. I left the theater feeling confused and uncomfortable. I was unable to suspend reality or immerse myself into the plot, but instead was very aware that I was watching a movie the entire time. The characters were not relatable, and the story was boring and did not inspire empathy.

I knew going into "The Fabelmans" that this movie was going to celebrate the love of cinema and more importantly the love of filmmaking. While it very much does that, I was more surprised to see what a great coming-of-age movie this is. It's about a family on the rocks and I could feel how personal this was for Spielberg. His direction is heartfelt and every scene kept me engaged. I thought the performances were all fantastic and there really isn't a weak link anywhere. I felt the movie also spoke to things I am personally interested in like Spielberg's life as well as his love for the movies and how it developed. I felt the ending of the film was a bit abrupt and think the movie could have shown even more story and been over three hours if it wanted to, and I would have been completely fine with that, which I don't say often. Overall, this is a movie that delivers that warm and sweet feeling I can safely expect with any Steven Spielberg project, and while it might not be the best movie he has ever made, it is still a fantastic one that is most definitely his most intimate and personal.
